instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message:
All power rails present except <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 0v AND  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0v
 Unable to get the datesheet of TPS51980A and pin2 is 0V. It was water damage. Any help please?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message: Where was the corrosion?? Resistance to ground on L7520? Corrosion on J6100?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message: Resistance to ground on L7520 is 1M and there is no corrosion on J6100. The board came as cleaned no visible corrosion.Thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message:
"All power rails present"
Almost all power rails require <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> presence; except 3V3 rails...
So you measure something wrong there.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> comes out from L7520, not from pin2 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message: My G3H, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> isol, ppdcin g3h, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> all are ok  and pp5v-s4rs3 is 0v and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is also 0v ( I checked double ). I am not saying <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>  comes from <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> just mention that PIN2 (V5SW) of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is 0 V. THANKS.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message:
So you don't have all power rails present.
In fact, apart of <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, you are missing all secondary voltages, on big coils...
Post values for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and all PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>=0v"
That is bad.

Measure resistance to ground on that line.
Also check <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message:
I am so surprised that now  <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>=3.2v
<RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR>=330k,
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.3v
thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message:
Solder an wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> pad and touch the ground with it.
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops to 0V at the same moment.
If yes, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> should rise to 0V too; at least check if is any pulse there...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light but no Fan spin
threads.message: Did ultrasonic cleaning and now back in normal. Thanks a lot for helping me to solve the problem.
